column1: What is the name of your institution?
column2: What is the location of your institution? Ex. Storrs, CT or Vancouver, BC
column3: Is your institution public or private?
column5: How much do you get paid per academic year to do the work of your assistantship? (Indicate currency, but no need to convert to USD)
column6: If additional funding is included as part of your standard financial package, how much of that do you receive per academic year? (DON'T include conference/research funding, special grants/fellowships, optional summer teaching--basically don't include any money you have to specially apply for or get through a reimbursement.)
column7: How many months of work does your assistantship cover?
column8: How many hours of work per week does your assistantship (supposedly) cover this term? (Just put the OFFICIAL number, there'll be opportunities to correct the record further down.)
column9: What kind of assistantship do you have this term?
column10: If you have a teaching assistantship, which option best describes your work this term?
column11: If you have a classroom-based teaching assistantship, how many courses or sections are you responsible for this term?
column12: If you have a classroom-based teaching assistantship this term, what is the MAXIMUM number of students in each class/section?
column13: If you have a teaching assistantship, how many hours a week do you ACTUALLY spend on that work, averaged across the semester? (Just put the number here, there's a comments section later.)
column14: If you have a research assistantship, how many hours a week are you tacitly or explicitly expected to spend on that work? (Again, just the number, save the rest for the comments section.)
column15: Are there (actual, not theoretical) opportunities for summer funding in your department or at the university in general?
column16: Are you barred from holding a job outside the university?
column17: Do you receive a tuition waiver?
column18: How much are you required to pay in student fees per term?
column19: Which of the following benefits does your assistantship include?
column20: Are the grad students at your institution unionized?
column21: How has COVID impacted the conditions of your work so far?
column22: And finally...any further comments?
column23: If you have a classroom-based teaching assistantship, which kinds of courses have you been officially told to prepare or prepare to assist in for the Fall 2020 semester? (Don't worry, there's a comments section later where you can share more.)

column21: It is business as usual, which is a problem. There is no paid leave for bereavement or other issues, there has been minuscule financial support (had to apply but the amount varied and it came with the asterisk encouraging you not to apply so as to not decrease the "pot" for others) which makes it more difficult for students who support extended family members who have lost income, the criteria for coursework has remained the same despite the fact that TAs as well as students do not necessarily have the "ideal" workspace at home for teaching or learning, etc.
column22: The inclusion of domestic partners on insurance says specifically same sex so does not include opposite sex domestic partnerships; working outside of university is allowed but difficult (illegal usually) for international students,.

column22:
Health insurance: We get a partial cost waiver from the university, so work out to paying about $1500 per year for insurance out of pocket.

Our union is pretty good about getting COL raises each year so fees and health insurance costs stay pretty flat. However, they do note that we're underpaid for our state (and haven't had much luck bargaining increases generally). CoL in Tallahassee is generally pretty low, which makes the stipend liveable assuming you have roommates, no dependents, and no external debt or large costs.

TAs take a class for two semester before becoming instructor of record, during which we're expected to prep most of our course material. Actual amount of work during semester as instructor of record largely depends on the amount of work you want to put into teaching.

column6: Just the above funding + summer (currently, I’m making around 6,000 this summer).

column22:
Summer funding is not really guaranteed. On a first come first serve basis but you can be dropped in favor for more experience instructors and adjuncts if you are a grad student.

Working hours have a range. Under normal circumstances 1st year grad students have heavier class load than upperclass grad students, they also TA within the department, then teach their second year 1-2 courses and also the pressure to be present or involved in everything adds more hours. Stipends are taxed. 

Working a part time job can be extremely stressful if you really are or want to be involved with your program and cohort. 

Outside funding is not publicly known. The department needs more information and resources communicated in a timely fashion.
